intro: Ferula ghorana, commonly known as the Afghan wormwood, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clustered umbels of small white or yellowish flowers. The plant produces a pungent, aromatic resin that has been traditionally used in folk medicine. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its roots are thick and fibrous. Ferula ghorana is often found growing in rocky, arid environments and is adapted to withstand harsh climatic conditions.
